etymology.interpretation: Literally “red radish/turnip,” naming the beet by its color and root form. Common in Cantonese-influenced regions (e.g., Hong Kong); Mainland Mandarin more often says 甜菜根.
etymology.simplification: Standard character simplification in the PRC: 紅→红 and 頭→头; meaning unchanged.

examples.chinese: 这家店卖新鲜的红菜头(這家店賣新鮮的紅菜頭)。
examples.pinyin: Zhè jiā diàn mài xīnxiān de hóngcàitóu.

examples.chinese: 我买了两个红菜头(我買了兩個紅菜頭)，准备做沙拉(準備做沙拉)。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ mǎi le liǎng gè hóngcàitóu, zhǔnbèi zuò shālā.
examples.english: I bought two beetroots to make a salad.

examples.chinese: 在香港的超市(在香港的超市)，常能看到标着红菜头的蔬菜(常能看到標著紅菜頭的蔬菜)。
examples.pinyin: Zài Xiānggǎng de chāoshì, cháng néng kàn dào biāo zhe hóngcàitóu de shūcài.
examples.english: In Hong Kong supermarkets, you often see vegetables labeled “beetroot.”
